name.text: Ys VI: The Ark of Napishtim

description.text: Got this on a sale along with memories and seven. The last of the "classic" Ys games.

sublists.name: Games Being Played
sublists.description: These are a list of games I'm currently playing.

description.text: Pretty good :) Ending was a bit disappointing, but the game was enjoyable. If Square had enough time and had a better ending for this game, that would make this game more enjoyable. That aside, the characters are lovable, the music is amazing and the story is brilliant. Maybe if I grew up with this game, I'd appreciate it more?

Hmm, the story was good, the music was great, but the battling didn't quite do it for me. The junctioning system is a love it or hate it thing, and I'm afriad I'm steering towards the 'hate it' side. This got a 7 purely because of the sweet story, the emotional music and the overall experience of everything except the gameplay. Still worth a play, and hearing the song 'Eyes On Me' by Faye Wong will always bring back good memories of this game :)
Real sad TT~TT But real good! Except Blitzball. That sucked.
Go ahead and bash this game, I really enjoyed it! I don't care if it's linear, it's got a good story, good music, good gameplay and good characters. That's a win for me!
Playing this game made me wish I was playing the first game. Although, they did get some bits right; like making paradigm shifts quicker.
Gotta love this classic! I always played it when I was younger. I was around 12 when I eventually beat it.

What an awesome game. Honest, I played the HELL out of this when I was younger. I eventually reached a point where I could beat the final boss without getting hit once. But, yeah, I really like this game. It might be a bit outdated today, but the memories that this game carries couldn't put this game anywhere less than 8.

The comedy, the gameplay, the music, the characters, everything about this game was awesome. Definitely one of the best games I've played. Hours, if not days, of my childhood was poured into this game, and I'm not regretting it!

When I watched the trailer for this game, I was very excited for it. I saw Rayman running around, kicking Rabbid ass and generally being awesome. However, I never really got to play this game until years and years after, and when I did get to play it, I was disappointed to find out that the trailer I remembered all that time was a lie and that the game was actually a Rayman party game. It was a shame; I really wanted to like this game.

This game is a party game, just like its predecessor, but since I played it on the DS I really didn't mind. I didn't expect it to be a perfect port from other platforms, and the games were pretty fun. That is to say, I played this game before I played and beat Rayman Raving Rabbids on PC, so I had no idea that this game was just following in the footsteps of the first game. Overall, it was pretty good. Nothing to write home about, though.

When I first saw this in an issue of PC Gamer, I think it was, I was really surprised. I eventually got the game, and I was playing it a LOT. What's there to say? Rabbids collect stuff to go to the moon. It's querky and silly atmosphere make it pretty memorable.

Ubisoft took a step back with Rayman and started making games like the old classic Rayman on PS1, except making it a bit more fluid with the movement. I think this was a good idea, now that Rayman and the Rabbids are two separate games. Rayman Origins also make the cast seem a lot more silly and ridiculous, which is unique and fun but I really did prefer how Rayman was presented in Rayman 2 & 3. Overall, the game itself was a decent platformer. I hadn't played a platformer like this in a while, and it was quite fun.

This is the Rayman game that came after Origins. It was more or less the same thing; they stuck to the same formula and pretty much the same graphics, and just added new stuff. That's not a bad thing; I thought it was pretty good! Really cool platformer and definitely worth a try if you grew up with Rayman.

I think this was my first Sonic game, and boy did it give me a good impression of the series. The story was feels, the gameplay was cool, the Chao garden was fun and enjoyable, the variety of characters kept the game fresh, and I just love this game to bits. I've been playing this game before I can even remember, and I still love it just as much.

I'm sure some people will grill me for saying this, but I think SEGA went the wrong way with this one. It was fun, I'll give it that, but there are some things about Sonic Adventure 2: Battle that doesn't deserve it the 8 I wanted to give it. This game was the one Sonic game I really wanted, but didn't knew it existed. If I had played this when I was little, then it probably would've hit an 8 or even a 9. It's still memorable, just like the first one, but I still prefer the first one simply becasue it had open-world hubs you could explore and I played it a lot longer.

The reason why I played EarthBound was because it was really popular and it was the inspiration for the game Undertale, so I decided to give it a go. I'm sure it was amazing back in the 90's, but playing it now doesn't feel as good. It's still a great game, and I don't regret playing it, but I don't think it lives up to the hype that everyone's giving it. Decent game though, pretty good. Good job Nintendo! I played this around a year after playing Undertale. Music was good, gameplay was alright, story was good, overall I enjoyed it, but not enough to play it again. Good experience.

Ah, this game. Some love it, some hate it. I love it. When I beat it, it reminded me of the games I used to play when I was really young (even though they weren't RPGs, which was weird). I definitely recommend it to other games, and if you don't like Undertale, then at least give it a go if you haven't played it. Try and ignore its fanbase; they're not a true representation of the game itself!

Played this when I was really young, too. Ah boy, I really liked the gameplay and visuals! It was different than to what I was used to, but still, it was very enjoyable. Like Rayman, I beat it years after I actually played it. I haven't got around to playing the other Crash Bandicoot games... definitely recommend this one, though!

Here's another classic I played when I was really young. It's probably the first game I played with a hub world where you could run around and do what you like, which I thought was very good. I liked how you could pick an item in the hub world and it would take you to a level which represented an episode of Rugrats. Despite never watching the series, this game was nice!

I only really played this one because it was about Rugrats and it's on the same platform as Search for Reptar. It wasn't a game I grew up with, so I'm not rating it as highly as Search for Reptar or Warped. However, it was a good experience so I will credit it a score CLOSE to 7.

A neat dating sim if you've never played a dating sim before (like me). Think of Bejeweled, but with naiiize grills. Oh, and keep an Excel spreadsheet open while you play it; you'll need it. I really liked the characters, they were all unique, and I liked how it merged arcade game style with dating sim. I like it! I felt the end was a bit... unfulfilling, even with the new Valentines update. Ah well. Still a great game :)

Now here's a classic Valve game that I'll always appreciate. It's a first-person puzzle game, and you play as Chell as you go around solving puzzles with your portal gun, and you eventually discover the secret of Aperture Science. The first game was really fun to play, and listening to what GLaDOS had to say was quite entertaining. There's not much story involved in this one, but in Portal 2, a lot more story is incorporated.

This is a good game. Really. It really is good. Even though all the characters are robots, you feel for all of them (yes, even Wheatley). It's just so dramatic and story-driven and just generally amazing that it really caught me off guard when I played it, because none of those features were in the original Portal game. I'd definitely recommend the Portal series to someone who hasn't played any Valve games before.

This is another game I might be grilled for. People make out Half-Life 2 to be a classic. I agree with them, but only because of nostalgia. I've played Half-Life 2 for a long time, and I did enjoy it back then, but coming back to it now, I eventually reach points in the game where it feels like it's really boring and repetitive. I'm sure this game was at its peak back when it was released, but you need to have a lot of patience to play it now. That aside, the story is really good and the graphics were great for its time. It's a good game!

The sequel to Half-Life 2. It's a pretty good game, and the story follows on well through its predecessor. You would only really play it if you enjoyed Half-Life 2, though. I did back then, so I did play this game.

The sequel to Half-Life 2: Episode One. I remember having trouble trying to get this game to work after a certain point, so I had to use a save file I got online to continue through the game. That aside, it's more-or-less the same as the previous two games, except the story is a follow-on. The ending was really shocking! Unfortunately, I don't think we'll see a Half-Life 2: Episode Three anytime soon...
A pretty decent zombie FPS from Valve. Not much of a story, just kill zombies and go to places. It's a good way to pass the time, and pretty fun.

The sequel of Left 4 Dead. It's pretty much the same thing, but with different characters and they do different things. You really start to bond with the characters in the games, for some reason, even though they don't really do much.

15 high-school students, all with a unique talent, are trapped in a high-school and forced to kill each other to escape. It's the perfect mix of mystery, psychological, suspense and action. I've never seen better character development from this game; you learn to love each and every character from this game and when you see the corpse of one of your favourite characters, nothing explains how heart-ripping that is. I'd DEFINITELY recommend this game to a friend, just be sure to play it with Japanese voices, not English voices!

You know how Pokemon Gold/Silver took everything Pokemon Red/Blue had, and made it better? Well, Danganronpa 2 took everything Danganronpa had and multiplied it by 10. You not only have murders, but you have a crazy lucky guy, a perverted chef, a paradise island, a gamer waifu, and best of all: more psychological goodness! This is the very rare instance that the sequel is better than its predecessor, and this game is a must-play if you've beaten the first game but not the second. Again: play with Japanese voices, not English!

Kingdom Hearts is about a boy named Sora who discovers that he can wield the Keyblade, and he, along with Donald and Goofy, goes on an adventure to save the world from the Heartless and stop Ansem from reaching Kingdom Hearts. It has real-time battling, and is a very enjoyable RPG with Disney and Final Fantasy characters. Awesome game!

Like the first game, but everything is improved. Oh, and the story just got more complicated. A LOT more complicated. But everything that's been added to Kingdom Hearts II is an improvement from the game before. It's a really good game! A little sad, though; if you've played 358/2 days before-hand.

This game details the events of before Kingdom Hearts, the first game. It's pretty good, and deviates away from the traditional games, like the portable Kingdom Hearts games usually do. I preferred the traditional gameplay style, but this game was still really fun, especially grinding to get all of the best spells in my arsenal possible!

This game used cards instead of normal fighting, like the traditional games. You either love it or hate it, and I hated it. I suppose it's nice to have a change for once, but this was a bad change, and I don't like bad changes that I can't adjust to. Nonetheless, it helps tie in Kingdom Hearts and Kingdom Hearts II. Don't play II before the first game! Play this game first, then II.

Ah, the original Legend of Zelda! I played this a bit when I was younger. Not Rayman young, but... young-ish. Year 7? If you're not British, then... around 13 years old? I really did like the original Zelda, but I needed a walkthrough to beat it. It was very cryptic, but back at the time, this was unique. I'm sure if I played this back in the 80's, it would've been a masterpiece, but I played this game 20-30 years too late!

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time

description.text: When I beat this game, this game was all I could think about for the next month or so. I can't quite pinpoint it, but something about this game was simply marvelous. I reached a point where I could beat the entire game without looking at a walkthrough once!... Ok, that might not be very impressive, but I loved this game a LOT. Unfortunately, at the time I didn't have any friends who played Zelda, so I was on my own. This game is AWESOME!

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess

description.text: People say that this is one of the best Zelda games, and Ocarina of Time's second successor. I don't think that's true. I'm probably going to be beaten up for this by the Zelda community, but I think other Zelda games trump Twilight Princess easy. It was a good game, don't get me wrong, but it just didn't have that... spark that Ocarina of Time or Majora's Mask had. I don't know, I just didn't like it as much as I probably should've. Having said that, it's still a good game and worth it if you love Zelda!

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker

description.text: Wind Waker was a fun game. It was so cool exploring the islands and seeing what was out there; it was the first time I felt like I was genuinely exploring in a Zelda game. It's not as amazing as Ocarina of Time or Majora's Mask, but it's definitely worth playing and is a very good experience.

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword

description.text: This game was pretty fun, despite the motion controls. The characters were awesome, the dungeons were great and I loved flying around! People give this game a lot of hate, but I enjoyed it quite a lot.

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask

description.text: This game is the true successor to Ocarina of Time. Man, this game is depressing... it feels like the original Ocarina of Time, except you never play as adult Link. You have three days in which to do everything, and you can restart these three days. Initially, I hated this mechanic, but then I grew to appreciate it after playing it. This is a good game!
Please don't ask.
A classic game for the NES. It might not be much now, but playing it still feels really good for some reason. I did beat it once, with save states, so I don't know if that counts (probably not).

Wow, this game brings back memories. I played this game a LOT; heck, I even made videos about this game when I was 9. My very first YouTube video was a video about Mario 64, so I've had a lot of history with this game. This awesome game brings Mario into proper 3D, and includes features that were never before seen in Mario games. This game has a hub, and I love games with hubs that you can run around and explore.
This game was pretty cool; it was really fun running around planets and watching the camera move around the planet! Classic 3D platformer, as Mario should be.
This RPG was really cool back in the day; the music was especially awesome. I don't know what it was, but when I beat this game, something inside me just knew that I had just beaten an awesome game.
A pretty fun party game for the Wii. What else is there to say? Oh, yeah; there's this story mode bit, and that's kind of interesting. Apart from that, minigames and laffs for everyone!
This was a surprisingly short game, but considering it was on Game Boy, it didn't surprise me. It was fun to put this game on my phone and play it during tutor and free periods!

One time, a girl in my class said she fully completed Mirror Cup in Mario Kart Wii. This made me a little mad, because I hadn't done that, and I didn't want to be beaten by a girl back then, so I sweated this game until I fully completed it. It was a tough time, but I made it.
Ah yes, the game of broken Meta Knight. Many battles were fought, even more lost. I don't even know how that makes sense.
Ooh boy, this game was amazing. The characters were awesome, the story was brilliant, and it just felt so good to rub a contradiction in someone's face!

name.text: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Justice for All

description.text: Hmm, this one was alright. It was a pretty good Ace Attorney entry, but the music wasn't as awesome. I still preferred the first and the third one to this one.

name.text: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Trials and Tribulations

description.text: This one was kind of sad. It was a really good entry to the Ace Attorney series, and I loved Godot!
Yeah, you could still rub things in people's faces, but it's just... not the same! Hobo Phoenix is cool and all, and I don't dislike Apollo, but this entry just felt... meh.

name.text: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Dual Destinies

description.text: Did you like presenting evidence? Well, now you can present evidence with three attorneys! Oh, yeah, the story is pretty good, too.
Now you can play as Edgeworth and walk around, looking at things, using his special power: Logic!
This one wasn't as good as the first one, but I still really wanted to play it. The ending felt a bit too cliché. But logic chess was awesome! I really liked that.

name.text: Professor Layton and the Last Specter

description.text: This was my first Layton game, and I accidentally played the American one instead of the European one. I'll never make that mistake again! I still get nightmares of American Luke. *shudders*...

name.text: Professor Layton and the Miracle Mask

description.text: This one was on par with Last Specter, I believe. It was sort of a filler game towards Azran Legacy, but still a really good game.

name.text: Professor Layton and the Azran Legacy

description.text: Ah yes, this game was pretty nice. I really liked the ending, because it tied in so well with Curious Village.

name.text: Professor Layton and the Curious Village

description.text: For the first Layton game, it wasn't bad, but I prefer the later ones.
Ah yes, this game was pretty sad. Then again, aren't they all?

name.text: Professor Layton and the Lost Future

description.text: This is easily the best Layton game. It was so sad at the end! You really feel sorry for Layton.
I was so happy when I heard this game was getting a Western release, and I got one almost as soon as it was released. I was not let down.
This was one of the first Gameboy games I got. A lot of memories in this one!
I got this around the same time as Red. They're pretty much the same game.
Brock was so hard to fight with Pikachu. If it wasn't for Butterfree's Confusion at level 10, I would never have beaten this game.
This took everything Red/Blue had, and made it better! The phone was pretty cool, and the night/day thing was a unique and nice feature.
My childhood, right here: my first Pokemon game. I loved the contests, but there was always that one douche who would mess up everyone's score.

Just like Sapphire, but a few Pokemon showed up that I didn't really recognise at first. It didn't really have any emotional impact on me because I grew up with Sapphire, not Ruby, so it has the same score as Emerald.
Pretty much the same as Sapphire, but a few changes here and there. I beat this wayyyy after I beat Sapphire.
Gen 4 was OK. Nothing great, though. Maybe if I had played this when I was younger, I'd like it more?
The Pokemon game with the best story! I really liked N, for some reason. He was just really cool.
This was OK. It wasn't as good as the original Black, but I thought it was worth playing.
This Pokemon game was really easy; no grinding was necessary. I beat the Elite 4 and the Champion on my first go. Cynthia would be disgusted.

name.text: Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Blue Rescue Team

description.text: It was so sad at the end when my Pikachu friend turned into a normal, regular Pikachu. I was heartbroken.
This was an interesting RPG I picked up at BlockBusters, back when it was still around. It's not the best, but it's worth a play. It's a pretty cool RPG. The ending is very interesting.
Easily my most favourite RPG of all time. It really pushes the boundaries of the Wii, and it looks really beautiful. The music, the characters, the story, it's all amazing.
This game, along with Xenoblade, was released in the West due to Operation Rainfall. It's a pretty good RPG, but Xenoblade is better.
This game was kind of disgusting, but if you look past that, it's a really decent game. Think Zelda, but more dungeons.
Yeah, OK, I beat this game on creative mode. It still counts. I used to play Minecraft a LOT, but kind of stopped after Microsoft took over.
Decent 3D platformer, was pretty challenging near the end and I overall enjoyed it.

This game was a decent Kingdom Hearts entry; I liked the Flowmotion feature and I LOVED the scenes with characters that technically weren't supposed to be there. Oh, and Lea/Axel. And the bit that happened with him at the end :O !! This game is a sort of set-up for Kingdom Hearts III, but it'll be a long wait until I play that...

Pretty good. Decent story, although Black & White's story is still better. The battle mechanics suck though; they were really flawed. Apart from that, I really liked this game, but I still prefer the 2D Pokemon games.

Pretty good Mario game, to be honest. It's no Mario 64, but I enjoyed playing it. It was fairly challenging, but I felt the game gave me too many 1-ups and Super Stars. I gave this game the same rating as Super Mario 3D World, because what I felt from that game I shared with this game. All in all, this Mario entry was fun! (P.S. The baby Yoshi look weird)
It's OK, the story was pretty good but it made me wish there were more part members than just Lightning, like in Final Fantasy XIII.
Really good unique platformer, something I would've played during my childhood. Surprisingly sad ending, though! That ending bumped it up from a 7 to an 8.
Very good RPG, I liked the urban feel of it. The story was pretty good and dramatic, too, and I liked the unique battle style. Music is awesome, too!

name.text: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Spirit of Justice

description.text: Objection! This entry was pretty good. Not as good as Trials and Tribulations, but still pretty good and worth playing. However, the story was probably the saddest out of all the Ace Attorney games, with Trials and Tribulations coming close from behind.
I really loved this game, but I had to bring it from 8 down to a 7 to account for my nostalgia a little bit. It's a good game, but it does have its flaws.
Really fun! It's like New Super Mario Bros U, but it's all about speed.
Really fun platformer! It's very challenging, too. Definitely recommend it if you're an AVGN fan, like I am.
Decent JRPG; the music is good and the gameplay is good. The story isn't really much to write home about, though.
A part of my childhood right here. The story is nothing to write home about, but it's well executed and funny. The music is pretty good too.
I played this because of how much I liked Space Quest. It's OK. That's it, really.

name.text: Danganronpa Another Episode: Ultra Despair Girls

description.text: A pretty fun third-person shooter! The story is nothing special, but kind of important for Danganronpa 3. It's also very dark, just as dark as the main series, which is good. Overall, if you really like Danganronpa, play this, but if you're only in it for the story, then you could just read a synopsis of this.

This is a pretty decent JRPG. The gameplay is very similar to Kingdom Hearts, so if you like that, you'll really like this. The story is nice, and the music is really good. Plus, I unlocked all the achievements for this game. Just thought I'd say that.
Decent RPG, I preferred the original though. The story was decent, but it was too open-ended. If they had concluded the story properly, this game might have earned an 8.
Really good entry to the series; music was good, gameplay was good, story was decent. Ending was OK, but all in all good game.

Strongly reminded me of Sonic Heroes, so it gave me a sort of half-nostalgia. I believe it's the last game before Yuji Naka left, and the last of the classic Sonic games, at least for me. Good game; I liked how you could pick sides. Only problem was that sometimes you had to play the same level so many times to get all the endings.
Very good game, would definitely recommend to a friend. It executes horror very well, and doesn't use any cheap methods like jump-scares.

It's good, strongly reminds me of Sonic 3 and such. Unfortunately, I liked games like Sonic Adventure more than games like Sonic 3 & Knuckles, so this game fell a bit short for me. It's still a great game, though.

Eh, this game wasn't that great. Story felt too short, the game was WAY too short (only 3 hours) and the gameplay was bland at times. One of the good things about it was its music, though. The music was really good. Plus, the visuals were nice, but I guess all the budget went towards that. I guess a good word to describe this was 'mediocre'.

Another childhood classic! I tried to be a bit more objective here and not let my nostalgia take me too far away... It's a standard arcade game, just like Snow Bros for NES. It's not a special game, but I mostly enjoy it because of my nostalgia. Apart from that, the game is fairly mediocre. It's still pretty enjoyable, even today, though.

I suppose this game isn't much of an achievement; it only took me around an hour or so to beat. Still, it's another childhood game and still worthy of being on the list. Like Snowy, the nostalgia is the only thing that puts this on this list. If it wasn't for that, I probably wouldn't have bothered.

Good game! Very hard, though. The visuals are good, the music is good, the gameplay is very good, the controls are nice (I used a controller) and overall this was a good experience. It can get very frustrating though!

name.text: Fragile Dreams: Farewell Ruins of the Moon

description.text: Good RPG, very good story. The music will put you to tears; definitely the type of game that will give you feels. Truly a hidden gem on the Wii library, like The Last Story and Xenoblade Chronicles (not sure if that's 'hidden' anymore but eh).

Very enjoyable entry to the Layton series. The music was good, comedy was on point, characters were interesting and I just generally liked it. It was left very open-ended, which is fine if Level-5 will have follow-up stuff, which they are: an anime series. Hopefully the anime will explain more stuff, like Sherl and Kat, and hopefully it'll have the Professor himself in it!
A great game from my childhood. It definitely aged well.
Another Kirby game from my childhood. It's the same as Kirby's Adventure, except it's on GBA.

I started playing this because I wanted my friend to hurry up and finish Fire Red so we could start Pokemon Sun and Moon at the same time. I beat it in less than a week, mainly because I had speedhacks on. It's decent, and it's objectively a better game than the originals, but I'll always prefer the original games partly due to nostalgia and their simplicity.
A very good game. The gameplay is definitely an improvement over the first game, but the story of Xenoblade 1 is still the best. Overall, it was a fun experience.

Even though it's a fan-game, it feels just like a real Pokemon game! I really liked how you could actually see your IVs and EVs, and the training you could do for it (similar to Super Training in Gen 6). Additionally, I thought the story was pretty decent; it wasn't too complicated (which would've broken the Pokemon aesthetic), and it was still deep and effective. The Nuclear type was pretty cool, but I never used it. You can really see the work put into it, and I'll recommend this fan-game to any Pokemon fan.
A clever "MMO" that I grew up with. It would've been a 7, but it gets the extra point for nostalgia.
One on my games from my childhood! Really fun
Another of my games from my childhood! Really fun
A great game for English students or something
Another great game for English students or something
A good mega man game
Underrated DS rhythm game that I really enjoyed. Features lots of classical music!
Good Sonic game. I can see the parallels between Mania and CD after beating it.
Pretty good; quite challenging. I beat it with both Sonic and Tails.
I beat the game, but I didn't collect all the chaos emeralds. I couldn't be bothered. Perhaps I'll do it on the '& Knuckles' version.
A childhood game of mine! I'm glad I finally got this one done. The final zone and boss was really hard, so I don't feel like getting all the Emeralds and achieving the true ending for this.
A childhood game of mine! It's really hard at the end, but I'm glad I beat it. The ending glitched out, I think, so I wasn't able to see it.
Good game. What I'd expect from Sonic. I only completed this with Sonic, and I didn't collect all the Emeralds.
Good remake, it didn't feel like they changed too much from the NES version, and it still felt fresh and fun.
A good horror game.
Another good horror game. I think I got the true ending.
Yet another good horror game.

To be fair, a bit of nostalgia might've affected that rating. I beat the game properly by getting all the Chaos Emeralds and getting the true ending. I used save states to get the Emeralds, but everything else was purely legit.
A great funny point-and-click adventure game!
Another childhood point-and-click adventure game! Pretty good.
A classic adventure game I played in my childhood (and got nightmares from). Short, but fun.
Definitely would recommend it to a Final Fantasy 7 fan, quite insightful for the story.

name.text: Baldi's Basics in Education and Learning

description.text: It's alright, but once you know what to do, it turns into a game of extreme luck.

A good Sonic game, felt a bit more platformy than the previous ones, but still decent. The ending is really wholesome and cute. The gimmick of pairing up with someone else is interesting, but I never really utilised it to its full potential. To be fair, I used a code to give myself all the Chao and the SP keys, but I did all the levels, all the bosses and all the special stages.
Amazing game, awesome story
Yet again, amazing game, awesome story
Not as good as Walking Dead, but still really good
Pretty good
Pretty good too

name.text: Back to the Future: The Game

description.text: It's good

Pretty good Sonic 2D platformer, I really liked the tricks mechanics and the boost feature that wasn't in Advance, which makes this objectively the better 2D platformer (despite my nostalgia!). Although, there are significantly more cheap deaths, so overall, it's as good as Sonic 3 & Knuckles.
One of the best, if not THE best, 2D Sonic platformer I've played. Like Sonic Rush, but less cheap deaths and more stuff to do.

A very interesting game, I really liked the fourth-wall breaks, like when you have to move files into another folder, or when you needed to close down the game to access a different room. The sprites are cute, and you get attached to the characters. The music was good, but not Undertale-level good. I also really liked how it incorporated the player as a separate character; I really felt like Niko was interacting and talking to me, and I really enjoyed the talks with him, comparing his world to mine. Towards the end, the story got a little hard to understand, as things were moving really quickly and I wasn't sure if some story bits were trying to be fourth-wall breaks or just story bits localised within the game itself. All in all, a fun puzzle game with very interesting fourth-wall breaks and heart-warming characters, but don't expect it to be the next Undertale!

This is an awesome game. I got it with a bundle, including a PS3 console and a bunch of other games for £30 second-hand. The story is great; it gets real at places! The helicopter and flying bits were a little awkward, and sometimes the game would crash on my PS3, but overall it was fun.

Almost everything about this game is absolutely perfect. The music, the gameplay, the visuals, the characters, Gears for Breakfast got pretty much everything spot-on.

It was really fun exploring the worlds, and they weren't just open fields (like on Ocarina of Time or something), there was stuff to collect and things of interest to check out.

The levels and bosses were fun and engaging, the story was funny and the humour was surprisingly mature for a game that looks so innocent and child-friendly.

The only complaint I would have with this game is that it can be a little too easy; I never felt truly challenged in the game. Sure, there were levels where I died a few times, but no levels where I had to start seriously sweating to complete. There wasn't even a 'hard' difficulty to pick, unless you count the 1-hit death badge, which doesn't really count.

However, apart from that, every other aspect of this game is absolutely amazing and I would strongly recommend this to anyone who grew up with 3D platformers like I did. It truly is a masterpiece of a game.

To add to this, I beat the Seal the Deal and Nyazuka Metro DLCs. I completed all of Death Wish! It was really hard, but very fulfilling; I felt like I did something not many other people can do. Generally, I loved Seal the Deal, but Nyazuka Metro felt a little lacking. I like the cutscenes, and the new world was awesome to explore, but it felt like the ending cut it a bit too short, as if it was unfinished or something.
I beat this with a friend. Decent game.

To start off with, the Sonic stages. They were fun to play, I liked the different paths you could take (with the ones requiring better reaction times being more rewarding) however drifting was a little weird. The werehog stages got a little boring at times, and the platforming wasn't executed very well. The story was good though, the ending was feels and the music fitted the game very well. The cutscenes were the best thing about this game though, they were so much fun to watch! Overall, the game was good, but they could've made the werehog stages more fuelling and something more than just 'move from one room to the next beating up purple bees and suffering through bad platforming'.

For a pound on Steam, this was a pretty good game! The mechanics were fun, I liked the powers, the 3D platforming was well executed and I loved the humour. All in all, this was enjoyable and I'll be looking forward to seeing what the sequel brings.

name.text: Doraemon: Yume Dorobou to 7 Nin no Gozans

description.text: Quite a short game. I beat the Normal and Fun game modes. I grew up with this game; I used to play it in Thailand back when I was around 9 or something. I couldn't get past the first level... but now, I find this game pretty easy. I wish I could've read the dialogue (it's all in Japanese), which means I had to guess what to do. The rock paper scissors bit was the most confusing and took some time to understand. All in all, a fun little platforming game, but it's only 20 minutes long.
This is an awesome puzzle-fighting game! Think of puyo puyo, but more... crystal. I spent so many hours of this game when I was younger. It's very addictive!
A really fun, difficult platformer! Short game, though. I haven't done all the B-sides or chapter 8 yet.
Really weird but fun game! If you like games like Space Quest, Monkey Island etc. you'll love this! It's from my childhood, too.

Great game! The gameplay and battling is awesome, very reminiscent of Cuphead in both art style and bosses. I liked the music too, it really fitted the atmosphere and the themes of the game. The one thing I didn't like was how far away the benches were from the bosses. The bosses in this game take a couple of attempts to beat, but when I'm fighting a boss I don't want to spend half my time walking to the boss; I want to be actually fighting it. To be fair, some bosses had benches that were close to them (like Hollow Knight and Hornet) but some didn't, which was very annoying. Apart from that, I enjoyed the game. Even though I'm usually not a fan of backtracking, this game executed it well. To compare this game to others, I'd say it's like Metroid, but with a short-range weapon with physics like Celeste.
Fairly good tactical game. Story was nothing to write home about, music was good, all in all decent game.

name.text: Xenoblade Chronicles 2: Torna – The Golden Country

description.text: It's pretty much an expansion of Xenoblade 2, so I gave it the same rating. The story was decent, although most of it was stuff I already knew. It pulled it off similar to how Crisis Core was to Final Fantasy 7, plus I really liked how the story ended where Xenoblade 2 begins! Plus, the new battle theme is awesome. Nearly all the other tracks come from the original game, though. Also, there was two parts where the game forced you to do side-quests to progress. Although at first I did find that annoying, it quickly grew to me and actually turned out to be a little fun (not to mention rewarding, I didn't realise side-quests give so much bonus XP!), and it executed it better than Xenoblade X (which felt like an obstable/chore). All in all, I really enjoyed this, and I would recommend it to anyone who beat the main game of Xenoblade 2.

Great games, the story was good, the music was amazing, the gameplay felt fun, it was generally a really good experience. Only complaint was that sometimes it's not quite clear what to do next, which is why I used a guide, but that's quite minor (lots of older RPGs are like that). Considering these games are around 30 years old, they've modernised it really well!
Great game! Great story, great music, great gameplay, I just really like this game. Same creator as Ace Attorney!

name.text: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Conflict of Interest

description.text: A decent fan-game, if I'm honest! I felt that PyWright limited it a bit, because it's a little buggy. The story was pretty good, although it was hard to follow at times (what Ace Attorney game isn't?). It reminded me a lot of Pokémon Uranium, however that fan-game did a much better job of looking legitimate.
Pretty good game, I liked the fusion feature!

It's alright. I finished the game on Easy and Original mode, and I got the perfect ending with all the secrets. There were good things about it, and bad things about it. I would definitely not say that this is a masterpiece, but at its time, I can understand the appeal. A common thing in games like this is things like unskippable cutscenes and putting the last save point ages away from the boss I'm fighting. When I'm fighting a boss, I much prefer restarting right before the boss instead of starting at a save point 30-60 seconds away from the boss. It doesn't feel challenging, it's just annoying. The challenge should be in the game itself, and should make me want to overcome the obstacles. Additionally, I felt the physics were a bit floaty; I'm more of a fan of rigid, robust controls. On the other hand, the music was good, the graphics were amazing and the story was decent. Overall, if the save points were closer to the bosses, the physics was more rigid and the cutscenes were skippable, I might've given this an 8.

A very good game! I first played Yunica's story on Medium, and then I played Toal's story on Very Easy to get through the story. It has a perfect mix of hack-and-slash and JRPG. The music is cool, the characters are awesome, the story is good (it gets even better on Toal's story) and I generally really enjoyed Ys Origin. A small complaint is that I wish the game forced you to beat Yunica's and Hugo's stories first before they let you play Toal's story, kind of like how Sonic Adventure would only let you play as Super Sonic once you've beat all the stories. I kind of regret not playing Hugo's story before Toal's. Toal's story is way better than Yunica's story, at least in terms of actual plot. I also loved the throwbacks to the previous games! It was definitely worth plowing through Ys I & II to play Ys Origin (not that Ys I & II were bad games).

I started it expecting my questions to be answered, and instead I get more questions! Great game, really good gameplay, classic Kingdom Hearts style as always. The music is good, but nothing new; it's all mostly rehashes and remixes of old songs, with the exception of Face my Fears and Don't Think Twice. The graphics are really good, definitely a step forward from older Kingdom Hearts games. I also really liked how free-roamy this entry was; there's a lot to explore. Plus, the gummi ship segments are actually fun! Furthermore, the towns don't feel dead and empty anymore; they're lively, full of people and fun to run and look around in. As for the story, it's what I expected, really. There were bits that were unexpected, but all in all, it went pretty much how I thought it would, with Sora defeating Xehanort. I think the Xehanort arc foreshadowed a bit too much, so the finale isn't that shocking; the expected happens. However, the best bit of the story was when Roxas made his return. That part was even better than the finale! There are some teasers for the next game, which I know will start a different arc. All in all, good game. I'm looking forward to the next entry!

Picked this one up during the Winter Steam Sale for £3! They say that this one is just as good as Origin, so I played this one. Well, one thing that it did better than Origin was that you can actually go outside and talk to people! There's only one village you can go to, but oh well. Origin did better in music and story; it wasn't bad in Oath, but I feel Origin did better. I suppose it's because Origin has different protagonists (ones that can actually talk). In terms of gameplay, Oath definitely feels more fluid. All in all, I'd say it's about equal to Origin.
Phew, this game was hard! It's basically a typing game based off Ys II. It got really difficult at the end, especially against Darm. It's a small game, so there's not much to say.

I just finished chapter 1, and I'm loving this game! Toby took the good things from Undertale and the good things from Earthbound and put them together. The story looks interesting, the music is great as always, and I'm really excited to play the rest when it comes out.
For what it's worth, it's pretty good. It's a very short test game, so it barely qualifies for this list, but I thought I'd add it anyway, seeing as how much effort went into the graphics and music.

Interesting game. I thought it was neat. I wouldn't say I like it or dislike it, I just appreciate the game for what it tries to do. To be honest, half way through I got a bit bored because it was literally just waiting for messages, and the in-game games, as cool as they were, got old quick. The ending was super cool, I liked how the room you were in was the elevator the whole time. I picked the option to leave the room, and I walked into Charlotte's bakery to read the message. All in all it's a neat game but I wouldn't play it again to get the other endings.

I stopped playing the original on PS2, but I replayed it in HD, on Steam. Good game! The music, visuals, story and characters were all creative and wonderful. It really captures the spirit of Japanese folklore. The ending was also really great, it felt fitting to the story. The only complaint would be the controls feel a bit slippery, especially when I'm doing platforming. Additionally, the first 10 hours were a bit slow, but after that, the game picks up momentum and draws you in more. Definitely a game I'd recommend to someone who likes Twilight Princess and Japanese folklore in general!
A fun game; it feels great to throw around people and chuck cars at them! The variety of guns also keeps the gameplay fresh and things to do open.
Good game, like the predecessor, but I felt the previous game was more stable. Still a good game though, and would recommend to someone who played the previous.

Got this on sale. A remake of the fourth entry in the series. It's my first modern Ys game! First thing's first, the gameplay. I feel it's the best Ys has done so far (then again, I haven't played 7, 8 or Ark yet). It feels so good to shield/dodge at just the right time and watch the game slow down! Plus, it's really dynamic and fast-paced. You can't jump, but I liked the skills and extra skills. All in all, I loved the gameplay; it was so refreshing and satisfying and I really hope the later modern Ys games are like that, if not better. I got the best weapon and armour in the game, fully upgraded, and I fully levelled my party, and it felt so amazing to run through enemies and kill everything in one hit! In terms of the party system, I didn't think much of it. I preferred it, gameplay wise, when it was just Adol. I felt I had more control. However, being in a party makes it less lonely! However, the AI isn't that great, so that feeling doesn't last long! The story is what I expected it to be; it's Ys, it keeps it simple yet good enough to make it interesting and make you want to keep playing. I do admit though, the ending felt too quick, but at least it was canonical (Adol never logged anything past the ending of the game in his books). I did like the bit at the end where Adol was the only one left to throw the mask into the volcano, although I felt Falcom could've made that ending segment a bit more dramatic. Fighting a phantom version of Gruda was cool, because his moveset felt very similar to mine, almost as if I was fighting myself, but what would've been more awesome would've been a three-phase boss of actual Gruda, who escaped Iris and wants to put Adol through one final test, with an intense rock remix of the main intro theme of the game! Speaking of music, I felt it was the worst part of this Ys entry. I often missed the intense, awesome rock music that you get from other titles like Origin or Oath. There were some, but often it felt a little generic. I love the intro song though; that's the best song for me! To be honest, speaking generally in terms of Ys, I would like it more if there was some kind of motif for the entire Ys series that played in every game, similar to Zelda. The controls were good. The best controls are when you don't think about it when you use them. It's nothing amazing, but they didn't screw it up either. The graphics were also decent. For a PSP Vita game brought to PC, it was pretty good. I prefer this art style to the previous art styles that Ys adopted; it feels more "anime". All in all, I'm really liking modern Ys! I can definitely see the differences between modern and classic. If I had to pick one, I'd say modern, although they both have their pros and cons.

sublists.name: Finished Games
sublists.description: These are a list of games I've finished. Not always 100%, but finished the main story, at least.

description.text: This game was really hard for me back then! I just never got around to beating it.
I really wanted to like this game, but the cameras just spoiled it for me. I can't play a game with a camera that makes me uncomfortable.
I already watched the PS3 cutscene film, so I didn't really see the point of finishing the game.

name.text: Zelda II: The Adventure of Link

description.text: It's a hard game, and eventually I gave up.

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: The Minish Cap

description.text: If I knew what to do at the very start of the game, maybe I'd like it a little better.

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: Oracle of Ages/Seasons

description.text: Good Zelda games, I just don't have the patience for them right now. Maybe later?

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past

description.text: People claim it's the best Zelda game, but I disagree. It's OK, but not great.

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening

description.text: I would've beaten this game, but I didn't have the patience for it.

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: Spirit Tracks

description.text: It was kinda cool to play as Zelda, but I didn't really have enough time to play it all.

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hourglass

description.text: Apparently, this game is really easy. Such a shame I didn't have time to play it all.
It was fun to pick things up and throw them at enemies. Yep.
This game was a fun NES game, such a shame it's so long and difficult.
Yet again, I never really got around to completing this one.
That damn baby... oh boy.
I wanted to play this because of Partners in Time, but I never really got around to playing it again.
I should've beaten this, but I haven't. I should've, though.
A classic platformer. It's just really hard.
Yeah, this game sucked. I didn't like it.

name.text: Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars

description.text: It's kind of long, so I never really got to complete it.
I was going to beat this game, but I reached a point where I didn't know what to do, so I quitted.
This is one of those games where you have to sweat to beat it. I didn't sweat.

name.text: Mario & Sonic at the Olympic Games

description.text: The DS game was alright. The Wii game sucked. I would've beaten the one on DS, if my save file hadn't have been deleted.
I admit, this is a good game. I just never got around to beating it. However, I did beat the HD PC port.
This game is hard. You really need to sweat this to beat it.
Once you've beaten Gold, you feel like 'What's the point?'.
I think I reached a point where this game got really hard, so I never beat it. Ah well.
Ah, my childhood again. I consider beating this game completing all of the main story campaign levels. I never did that. Too hard for 6-year-old me!

name.text: Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings

description.text: I only really played this a little bit. Not much. So I guess I never really tried to beat it.
I didn't really like the third entry. I wasn't really used to it; I preferred the first one out of all of them.
Wayyy too difficult for me. It does feel very retro, though!
Fun game, but I couldn't beat it. It's really long.

name.text: Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Time

description.text: I was really close to beating this, but then I just... stopped playing. I'm not sure why.
This is a fun platformer game, but some levels are really difficult.
The Western open-world RPG isn't really for me. Maybe I'll come back to it sometime?
Crappy game, do not play

It's decent, and I can see why people like it, but it's just not really my thing. The dungeon/mission segments are pretty boring, and I don't really like the idea of having to race around fetching pearls to make the story progress; I felt like it should've been an optional thing if you wanted to be stronger or something. Nonetheless, the story was pretty good, and the characters were cool. Plus, the music while you ride around in that boat out to sea was awesome. Unfortunately, it's just not a game I can see myself completing any time soon.

I played this game because it was considered a timeless classic, and everybody loved it. When I played it, it felt fairly mediocre. The controls were dodgy, the camera didn't feel natural and it felt like a giant easter egg hunt instead of a platformer. To be fair, most of those points are only because the game is old and hasn't aged well, which I can understand. However, I don't see myself beating this game anytime soon. I prefer the formula adopted by Super Mario 64, Super Mario Galaxy and A Hat in Time, where platforming was the main subject and collecting stuff was either optional or just a byproduct of completing levels (like the stars in Mario, or hourglasses in A Hat in Time). With Banjo-Kazooie, I felt they went a bit overboard with the collecting. It would've been better if the notes weren't required to progress, and if there was some kind of clue as to where the Jiggies were (like how Super Mario 64 has a title to each star). All in all, I can see why people love this game, but I am unfortunately not one of those people.

I tried replaying it a while back, but I come across the same problem each time I play this. It's too monotonous. All you do is go from one area to the next, killing things as you go. There's a little bit of story here and there, but for the most part, it felt like a chore to play.

I wanted to get around to playing this; it seemed really interesting. However, it's less of a "game" and more of an "interactive story", with a lot of walking around. That would be fine, if I actually knew where to go and what to do. Instead, you're wandering aimlessly around hoping that the next thing you bump into will progress the game. I can sort of see why it has such a big following, but this game just isn't for me.

I thought I would get into the Shantae series by playing the first game. The first game was clunky and uncomfortable to play. You can't even blame it on GBC, because there are some GB games that still feel great to play (like Super Mario Land). However, if this game got a remake or something, like how Falcom remakes the Ys games, I would definitely give it a go. The only thing stopping me from playing the rest of this game is the poor gameplay and controls.

sublists.name: Dropped Games
sublists.description: These are a list of games I've dropped. That doesn't mean I didn't like them, it just means I'm not playing them anymore.

name.text: The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild

description.text: This game looks really cool! As a Zelda fan, I'll definitely check it out.
I swear, I'll get around to playing this one day.
It looks really cool, and it has a PC release!

I want to try out a classic Final Fantasy, and since I've played Final Fantasy Brave Exvius (a lot) I already know some FF4 characters. I want to play the remake, because it's in 3D and it overall looks like a better experience. I haven't decided if I want to play it on PC or Android.
It looked like a cool indie game, so I added it to the list.
This had music that was in Sonic.EXE, so I'm interested.
Will definitely try this out and probably beat it when it comes out! Does that make me sad?
I've heard lots of great things about this entry!
Wanna get around to playing this :D
I grew up with 64, so hopefully Odyssey will be just as enjoyable.
I played the demo and really enjoyed it. It releases on July 13th, and I'm interested in playing it (when I get enough money to buy it).
I have the ROM patched and everything, I just need to get around to playing it!
Looks good
Looks like Sonic; I wanna try it.
Looks like a good Pokemon fangame
Gotta play this as per my Sonic marathon!
I played it a while ago, but I never beat it. I want to beat it.
Looks like a neat indie platformer
Heard a lot of great things about this game; it's got very good reviews, and awards!
Gotta beat this!
One of the composers is Yoko Shimomura, so I wanna check it out.
I played the demo on Switch, and I thought it was pretty good. It's like Fire Emblem, but with a recruitment system like Dragon Quest.
Saw this on the Nintendo direct, looked awesome!
Looks like Xenoblade X on steroids!
I played it once, but since I accidentally didn't save, I quitted. I want to get back into it!
This was released in American and several asian countries, but not in the UK yet, even though I had hype for it's release on the 27th. Waiting for that UK release!
I don't know much about this game other than it's a visual novel and a fighting game, but the soundtrack is awesome!
A friend of mine said this game was really good, so why not give it a go?
I've played every smash game up until this one, so I'd like to play it!
Looks cool, inspired by Pokemon so why not?
A sort of "prequel" to Xenoblade but not really, it looks cool
Looks really nice
This series looks cool, I'd like to one day try it

name.text: Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Sky

description.text: I dropped Time for some reason, so I want to play this again but with Sky instead. I actually want to beat it this time and further complete my childhood!

name.text: Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Gates to Infinity

description.text: Another Mystery Dungeon game I'd like to play.
Yet another Mystery Dungeon game I'd like to play.
HYPE
Another childhood game
Just bought it on Steam 75% off, so I wanna try this!
Another childhood game I never got to beat
Got this on a sale along with ark and memories.
looks good
Looks interesting! I've always been fascinated by interplanetary exploration. It'll take a while for me to play it though; it releases in 2020!
I got this during the Steam summer sale! I won't let the GB game put me off the series; I heard that it just didn't age well. I'll let this game decide the series for me.
I bought this during the Steam summer sale! It seems like an interesting game; it has very good ratings.
Ace Attorney is one of my most favourite visual novels of all time; why not give this a go?

sublists.name: Desired Games
sublists.description: These are games that I wish to play in the future, when I get around to it.

name.text: Super Smash Bros. for Nintendo 3DS and Wii U

description.text: I really liked this version of Smash, even if people call it casual. I mained Shulk, Little Mac and Cloud and I really liked how you could select Omega maps which were just flat. Plus, it wasn't too stiff like in 64 or Melee; it was just right.
Ah, who doesn't love Worms? Awesome artillery game!
One of my childhood games. Didn't play it a whole lot, though.
You could play this game today, and it would still be fun. In fact, I still do!
I remember having a demo for this, then years later, getting the actual game. I prefer Worms in 2D.
Same situation as Worms 4: Mayhem. I like 2D Worms better.
Interesting to see how they've changed Worms, but I would still prefer the older games.
It was always fun to play around with your favourite Valve characters... Not in that way!
I only really play it when I go to school and back. I don't go outside very often.
Ah, my first online game! Brilliant, this was. Until the expansion packs came along. The first two were OK, then it got weird.
My dad used to play this a lot, but I only played it a little bit. It's still fun, but I preferred WoW.

Ah, this game was a classic! You'd think it's babyish and weird, but it actually upholds a lot of common RPG conventions. I like how it contrasts child innocence and the adult world in the form of 'toons' and 'cogs'.

I guess it's fun making Mario levels, but as a programmer, I've designed countless levels, so it's nothing new to me. I'd rate this higher if the user levels weren't so weird. The event levels were fun though, because they were always about other franchises and I loved the costumes and amiibo support!

A mix of Final Fantasy and Brave Exvius, you can follow a main story or do side-quests  or do vortex quests, and you can pull units to join your party. The units are all from previous Final Fantasy games, with a few unique ones. It's really fun to build up a kick-ass party!
Very fun rhythm game for Switch. It's available on phones, but the Switch version is a lot better imo

sublists.name: Played Unbeatable Games
sublists.description: These are games that I can't beat, but I have played them.

sublists.name: Watched Films
sublists.description: These are the films I have watched already.

description.text: Really good film! Childhood classic

sublists.name: Films To Watch
sublists.description: These are films I want to watch in the future.

description.text: A cult classic

sublists.name: Read Books
sublists.description: These are the books I've read already.

name.text: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring

description.text:
Time for the unpopular opinion... I don't actually like Lord of the Rings that much.

In the books, there's just so much talking and back-story that hardly matters to the plot that it eventually becomes a chore to read. The Hobbit had a little bit of that, but most of the time something was going on and the characters were actually doing something. In LOTR, when everyone went to that elven place and held that meeting, there was so much talk and forgettable back-story that I felt it would be more interesting doing the washing up.

I still finished the book anyway, because I hate leaving things unfinished. I have watched the films, which are great, but I don't think I'm going to read the rest of the books any time soon.
Good book.

sublists.name: Books To Read
sublists.description: These are books I want to read in the future.

description.text: I hear every programmer needs to read this.

sublists.name: Anime being Watched
sublists.description: These are anime that I am currently watching.

name.text: JoJo's Bizarre Adventure Part 5: Golden Wind

description.text: ARI ARI ARI ARI ARI ARI ARI
WAN PAAAAAAAAAAAAAAANCH

sublists.name: Finished Anime
sublists.description: These are anime that I have fully watched.

description.text: It was decent. The fact that the protagonist was small and fat didn't bother me that much later on; I kind of got used to it.
I agree with others; the ending was kinda crap.
Sad anime! Not cry worthy or Clannad level, but it did have its feels.
Blue Exorcist was epic! I read the first two issues of the manga.

name.text: Baka to Test - Summon the Beasts

description.text: This anime was funny! Definitely recommend it as a comedy. Plus, the concept is pretty cool!
I would've liked this more, but the ship between Dino and Maika threw me off a bit. Other than that, a light-hearted and entertaining show!
Decent anime; it's what you'd expect. The plot is fairly standard, but the execution makes it really fun to watch.
See season 1 description
Underrated anime! Maybe that's because I just love the survival game genre so much.
I grew up watching the live-action, so seeing the animation and how it does things differently was interesting. It was just as feels as the live-action!
The first season was funny and enjoyable!
The second season was extremely sad. Near the end, it was just sad after sad after sad. Every consecutive episode I was holding back tears!

name.text: Code Geass: Lelouch of the Rebellion

description.text: Great anime, would recommend to people who have watched Death Note.

name.text: Code Geass: Hangyaku no Lelouch - Kiseki no Birthday Picture Drama
Code Geass: Hangyaku no Lelouch - Nunnally in Wonderland
Code Geass: Hangyaku no Lelouch R2

description.text: A good continuation of the series.

name.text: Corpse Party: Tortured Souls - Bougyakusareta Tamashii no Jukyou

description.text: Not much to say; it's only 4 episodes. It was decent.

Unpopular opinion time... I didn't like Cowboy Bebop that much. There was a disconnect between the characters, and I didn't really care that much for them. Plus, there wasn't any clear goal or problem or anything. I know that's the point, but it's not working for me.

name.text: Danganronpa 3: The End of Hope's Peak Academy - Hope Arc

description.text: A satisfying ending to the Hope's Peak arc! There wasn't much else they could've done, really.

name.text: Danganronpa 3: The End of Hope's Peak Academy - Future Arc

description.text: I loved the concept of the bracelets, where if you satisfied some condition it'll kill you, and nobody else knows your condition! That was so cool! Also, I loved how Danganronpa 2's cast came in at the end and saved everyone. People thought the mind control thing was bad, but I liked it; they executed it well, and it was literally a part of Mitarai's talent.

name.text: Danganronpa 3: The End of Hope's Peak Academy - Despair Arc

description.text: I love how slice-of-lifey this arc is! It's exactly what I'd love from Danganronpa; just a whole season of the cast just doing their normal school life with each other. Of course, there were also the serious bits. The first mutual killing game was the most shocking event in all of Danganronpa for me; it was just so brutal!

It was hype when I watched it, but eventually I couldn't wait long enough for the next episode to come out, so I just played the visual novel. Then I realised that the anime wasn't that great in comparison! The pacing is off, but as a recap, it's decent. It was also interesting to compare the anime and the game side-by-side.
The first half was awesome, but the second half got weird.
I remember starting this series off and finding it interesting, but I eventually lost interest.
Again, kind of survival game-y. Not as good as Future Diary or Btooom! though.
The perfect gateway anime for new weebs. Very clever!
I grew up watching this series, so I have very fond memories of it as a child. Surprisingly, Doraemon is really feels, for a kids show. It's such a shame you can't find all the episodes online!
A classic film! I probably watched this when I was younger, but I saw it again just in case.
A bit weird, but the gore was cool.

Yeah yeah, FBI open up, I actually like this show. For only 12 episodes, it was quite entertaining. Episode 11 really caught me off-guard with the Oreimo cameo! There were times where it was really funny, especially episode 12 (the fanservice episode ;D), which was the best episode for me. The OVAs were alright, too. All in all, a cute anime and definitely fitted the bill of an anime you casually watched now and then.
Decent film

Pretty good. Episode 1 was really gripping and dark, then it got a bit calm and even a little boring, until episode 7, which was again, really gripping and dark, then again it got calm and boring until episodes 11 and 12 which executed the ending pretty well.

Overall, I'd suggest this as one of those anime you casually watch and go into without any expectations instead of starting this thinking it's going to be the best thing ever. I think, with no expectations, one would enjoy Goblin Slayer better.
I really like the OP, and I thought this anime was interesting.
A pretty simple anime, something to watch casually.

name.text: The "Hentai" Prince and the Stony Cat

description.text: A pretty cool anime! Like others, it's quite chill.
Quite entertaining, and very interesting how they take actual past events and represent them.
This might seem like some casual ecchi at first, but it's actually pretty good.

I liked the mystery behind this! It's a bit gory, but it wasn't too weird like Elfen Lied; it pulled it off well. It's confusing at first, but then it makes sense. I loved the fan-service seasons at the end!

name.text: Higurashi no Naku Koro ni Kai

description.text: A good follow-up to the first season! It explains pretty much everything.
This was extremely feels

It was alright
That wing scene was cool, and the ending was satisfying.
This anime had the classic art style, and it first showed off Takumi. I liked the first stage.
Pretty forgettable. I can't remember what happens.
Kind of forgettable. Not much happens.
Third stage was cool, I loved the bit where Takumi had to apply his racing skills in an actual, intense situation, when he was chasing that guy!
I found this series very entertaining. It doesn't try to be anything more than it is; a senseless comedy. Plus, the concept is strange yet cool!
A neat anime, I liked the concept
A good entry to the series! Part 2 was better than part 1, and I loved the comedy of Joseph Joestar!

A really fun anime! I like how the concept is similar to that of a game.
Pretty forgettable. It got boring around the middle.
I keep hearing about how sad this anime is, but it's really not that bad. In fact, I got a little bored with it and forced myself through it.
Decent anime, very good animation and great music
Cool anime; a bit overrated though, but still very light-hearted and enjoyable.
Awesome anime! I'd like a Migi of my own. I like how it expresses humanity as a race.
Really light-hearted and fun! Definitely recommend to people who like slice-of-life.

name.text: KonoSuba: God's Blessing on This Wonderful World! 2

Good anime! Very Ghibli.
I was expecting it to be like The Cat Returns, but it wasn't. It's not really my thing but it was entertaining nonetheless.
One of the best anime I've ever watched. The way it handles the survival game genre is amazing, and the plot twists were great.
A good ending to to show.

Really overrated. It wasn't sad at all. Everyone was crying too much, and it generally felt artificial. Maybe because I'm not a musician, I can't relate? Plus, the "sad" twist at the end felt forced and cheap.
The first season is cool, but ended with too many questions.

The most motivating anime I've watched! Also the first proper anime I've watched, I think.

name.text: JoJo's Bizarre Adventure Part 6: Stone Ocean

description.text: It was a cool entry to the JoJo series, but I felt it was the weakest one. There were some stands that just felt stupid, and some battles that felt too ass-pully. Although, there were some cool bits, like Hermes' stand Kiss, and the Marilyn Manson arc had really good tension! Unfortunately, I was spoiled for the ending for Part 6, so I didn't get the full experience at the end. All in all, I'm glad I read it, but the other parts were better.

name.text: JoJo's Bizarre Adventure Part 7: Steel Ball Run

description.text:
Steel Ball Run was pretty good! It got a little confusing around the end, though. However, the stands were a lot better than Stone Ocean, as they actually made sense most of the time and weren't too "bizarre".

My favourite stand has to be Tusk Act 3; I love the concept of being able to move your body parts around anywhere you want, through holes you can move around the ground!

However, I didn't like the concept of spin. It felt too convenient and I couldn't grasp the boundaries of the power. It was like Hamon; it just worked.

On the other hand, I loved the way Steel Ball Run made itself bizarre, for example Diego's stand turning him into a dinosaur. It makes perfect sense, and it's a cool stand that's not too weird (like the stands in Part 6), but it's also really wacky and would make no sense out of context! If JoJo had more things like that, I would appreciate the series a lot more.

Additionally, I loved the sub-villain Ringo Roadagain. His stand was so simple, yet it was applied so well. 

All in all, Part 4 is still my most favourite part, but Steel Ball Run was definitely enjoyable and did have its great bits.

description.text:
I feel this show is overrated.

Every episode has the same structure: it has 50 minutes of boring talking, throwing around names I can't recognise of characters I don't care about, about politics that don't interest me. Then, in the last 5 minutes, they throw in a cheap cliffhanger that has hardly any bearing on the plot whatsoever. Whenever that happens, it infuriates me.

On the other hand, the acting was good and the environments and style felt fitting. The music was decent, but nothing struck me as amazing.
